Description: Basic concepts of data analysis and statistical inference, applied to one-sample and two-sample location problems, analysis of variance (ANOVA), and linear regression. Topics include probability models and statistical methods applied to practical situations and real-world datasets across various disciplines. The course also covers elementary statistical theory, including the plug-in principle, maximum likelihood estimation, and the method of least squares. A higher-level statistics course may be taken with departmental approval.
Prerequisites: MATH M212, M301, M303, or the equivalent.

Description: Introduction to major issues and approaches in artificial intelligence. Topics include principles of reactive, goal-based, and utility-based agents; problem-solving and search; knowledge representation and design of representational vocabularies; inference and theorem proving; reasoning under uncertainty; planning; and an overview of machine learning.
Prerequisites: Recommended: CSCI-C 343

Description: Covers the theory and practice of constructing algorithms that learn functions and make optimal decisions from data and knowledge. Topics include mathematical and probabilistic foundations, MAP classification and regression, linear and logistic regression, neural networks, support vector machines, Bayesian networks, decision trees, ensemble methods, kernel functions, expectation-maximization (EM), density estimation, model accuracy evaluation, normalization, and model selection.

Covers the algorithmic and practical aspects of discovering patterns and relationships in large databases. Provides hands-on experience in data analysis, clustering, and prediction. Topics include data preprocessing and exploration, data warehousing, association rule mining, classification and regression, clustering, anomaly detection, and human factors and social issues in data mining.

The main aim of the course is to provide skills to apply machine learning algorithms to real-world applications. The course focuses less on the number of learning algorithms and theoretical mathematics, and more on the hands-on skills required to make algorithms work effectively on diverse data sets.

This course discusses advanced signal processing topics as applications of machine learning. Students engage in hands-on signal processing tasks using a problem-solving approach to understand key machine learning concepts. The course aims to teach students how to systematically build intelligent signal processing systems.

The success of commercial search engines highlights the importance of Information Retrieval (IR) in helping users locate desired information. This course introduces the fundamental theories and concepts behind IR systems, covering techniques used in modern search engines. Students will explore these techniques and assess their significance through practical experimentation.

This course teaches the fundamental theories, algorithms, and key applications of network science across social and biological systems. It emphasizes hands-on learning using Python. Students are expected to have strong proficiency in mathematics and programming, including topics such as probability, statistics, linear algebra, data structures, and algorithms.
Prerequisites: Proficiency in mathematics and programming (including Python, probability, statistics, linear algebra, data structures, and algorithms)

Description: This course focuses on database models and systems, especially relational and object-oriented. It covers relational database design theory, structures for efficient data access, query languages and processing, database application development, and views. Additional topics include transaction management, concurrency, and recovery.
Prerequisites: CSCI-C 241, C 335, and C 343 (recommended)

Description: This course covers basic concepts of programming models and tools in cloud computing to support data-intensive science applications. Topics include cloud platforms, parallel algorithms, data storage, and high-level programming languages. Students will gain familiarity with a complex ecosystem of tools spanning multiple disciplines and learn about current research topics in cloud computing.
Prerequisites: Experience with Windows/Linux, Java, and scripting (recommended)

Course Title: Management, Access, and Use of Big and Complex Data
Description: Innovation today is driven by vast amounts of data from sensors, social media, and the Internet. This course explores knowledge representation, data processing, and data management for big and complex data. Topics include data integration, semantics, provenance, workflows, pipelines, and distributed NoSQL databases.

This course provides a foundational overview of the current database landscape, beginning with relational databases and SQL, and advancing to NoSQL databases such as XML databases, MongoDB, Neo4j, Cassandra, and HBase.

This course provides students with working knowledge on how to visualize abstract information and hands-on experience in applying this knowledge to specific domains, tasks, and diverse, possibly non-technical users.

This course teaches basic principles of human cognition and perception. It includes techniques and algorithms for designing and critiquing scientific visualizations across domains such as neuroscience, nanotechnology, biomedicine, IoT, and smart cities. Students gain hands-on experience using modern tools, 3D printing, augmented reality, and teamwork/project management.

This course covers numerical and graphical techniques for summarizing and displaying data, distinguishing between exploration and confirmation. It highlights the relationship with conventional statistical analysis and data mining, focusing on large datasets.
Prerequisites: Two graduate-level statistics courses or consent of instructor.

Description: This course provides a comprehensive survey of system and network security. Topics include threats to confidentiality, integrity, and availability, as well as defensive mechanisms. The course lays the groundwork for more advanced security topics and includes hands-on project-based learning.

Course Title: Organizational Informatics and Economics of Security
Description: This course explores how security technologies shape organizational structures by allocating power, determining authority, assigning risk, and shaping trust relationships. The course introduces core concepts such as security, privacy, and trust, followed by case studies examining real-world security technologies and their implications.

Course Title: Systems and Protocol Security and Information Assurance
Description: This course examines systems and protocols through the lens of security. Students learn how to design threat models and use various current security technologies and programming tools to mitigate vulnerabilities. The course includes significant hands-on lab work.

This advanced course covers in-depth topics related to network security, including adversarial modeling, cryptographic primitives (symmetric and asymmetric), and security heuristics. It addresses the ethical, technical, and theoretical aspects of security using real-world protocols. Topics include rational vs. malicious cheating, security reductions, and protocol analysis.
Prerequisites: INFO-I 536 is recommended.

Description: This course introduces students to the methodology and terminology of price theory. It covers partial equilibrium analysis, consumer and producer theory, welfare economics, price indices, revealed preferences, utility theory, and risk analysis. Emphasis is placed on comparative statics and duality theory.

This is a combined advanced undergraduate and graduate-level course providing an overview of health informatics. By the end of the course, students will understand and be able to apply informatics techniques to improve healthcare delivery and public health outcomes.

This course introduces foundational topics in bioinformatics, including sequence alignment and assembly, RNA structure, protein and molecular modeling, genomics, proteomics, gene prediction, phylogenetic analysis, and biological databases. It also covers experimental design, data mining methods, and the application of information and machine learning in bioinformatics.
Prerequisites: One semester of programming or equivalent knowledge (recommended).

Description: This course explores advanced bioinformatics topics through the lens of machine learning. It reviews hidden Markov models, neural networks, decision trees, stochastic grammars, and kernel methods, applying these to problems such as genome annotation, RNA and protein structure prediction, gene expression analysis, and integrative functional genomics.
Prerequisites: INFO-I 519 or equivalent knowledge (recommended).

Description: An advanced course in machine vision, covering concepts and methods used in digital image processing for artificial intelligence. Topics include local and global image tools, object recognition, and scene understanding using model-based techniques.
Prerequisites: CSCI-B 551 (Required).

Description: This course focuses on building foundational skills in machine learning, natural language processing (NLP), and AI. Emphasis is on applying these methods for data collection, analysis, visualization, and decision-making across diverse domains.

Designed to help students build and implement novel user interactions in mobile and pervasive systems. The course includes discussions on interaction paradigms and hands-on projects involving the design and development of computing applications in students' areas of interest.

This course surveys the field of HRI, examining how people interact with robots and designing systems for natural, human-centered interaction. Students engage with readings, design exercises, and the development of HRI prototypes.

An introductory survey of Human-Computer Interaction Design. The course explores interaction design, cognitive modeling, ubiquitous and affective computing, data visualization, and other themes through historical and modern lenses.
Provides a working knowledge of visualizing abstract information with hands-on application in specific domains, tasks, and for diverse user groups. Not for credit with both ENGR-E 583 and E 483.

Graduate-level introduction to social media mining. Includes hands-on work extracting social meaning (e.g., sentiment analysis) using automation and ML. Course includes literature review and critique of current SMM research.
Prerequisites: Basic Unix skills (recommended)

Description: Builds foundational skills in ML, NLP, and AI for data collection, analysis, visualization, and decision-making.
Covers fundamental theories, algorithms, and applications in network science, using Python. Requires strong proficiency in probability, statistics, linear algebra, data structures, and algorithms.
Prerequisites: Strong math/programming skills (required)

Description: Provides students with practical skills in applying data science to real-world problems. Students work in teams of 3–5 on problems defined by academic or industry sponsors. Focus on problem scoping, applying data skills, and testing solutions.
Integrates theoretical and practical components of the Information Architecture Certificate. Students work with a faculty advisor to define, implement, present, and defend a capstone project.

Covers the theory and practice of constructing algorithms that learn functions and make optimal decisions from data. Topics include probabilistic foundations, MAP classification, linear/logistic regression, neural networks, SVMs, Bayesian networks, decision trees, EM, model selection, and more.
Prerequisites: Recommended: Probability, Linear Algebra, Programming

Description: Explores algorithmic and practical aspects of discovering patterns in large databases. Hands-on experience in data preprocessing, clustering, classification, anomaly detection, and social issues in data mining.
Prerequisites: Recommended: Machine Learning or Programming Skills

Description: Focuses on practical skills to apply machine learning algorithms to real-world data. Emphasizes fewer algorithms with more hands-on practice and less theoretical depth.
Covers advanced signal processing topics using machine learning. Includes hands-on problem-solving tasks related to building intelligent signal processing systems.
Prerequisites: Recommended: Basic ML and Signal Processing concepts

Description: Teaches the pipeline for building state-of-the-art deep learning systems, including training mechanisms, GPU acceleration, parallelization, and deployment on low-powered hardware.
Prerequisites: Recommended: Python, basic ML or DL knowledge

Description: Covers theoretical and practical aspects of large-scale graph analytics. Applications include social networks, computational biology, and machine learning. Includes use of HPC frameworks and parallel graph algorithms.
Prerequisites: Recommended: Data structures, algorithms, Python/Java

Description: Explores relational and object-oriented databases, relational design theory, efficient data access, query languages, views, concurrency, and recovery.
Prerequisites: CSCI-C 241, C 335, and C 343 recommended

Description: Introduces programming models and tools for cloud computing. Covers parallel algorithms, storage, high-level cloud languages, and modern research topics.
Prerequisites: Experience with Java, scripting, and Linux/Windows

Course Title: HPC and Cloud for Large Scale Image Applications
Description: Discusses big data techniques for remote sensing and sensors. Includes architectures, image analysis systems, software, streaming vs. batch processing, and user interfaces.
Prerequisites: Recommended: Python, Java, ML or image processing basics

Description: Offers a broad overview of big data problems and solutions. Covers cloud technologies, algorithms, and includes a project.
Provides hands-on experience in visualizing abstract data for different domains and user groups. Covers tools and visualization techniques. Credit not given for both ENGR-E 583 and E 483.
Teaches cognitive principles and techniques for designing scientific visualizations across fields like bio-medicine, IoT, smart cities. Includes tools like AR/3D printing and project teamwork.
Prerequisites: Visual design and data familiarity recommended

Description: Covers Cloud 3.0 concepts: DevOps, Microservices, and Function as a Service. Project-based course using Apache Big Data Stack and integration techniques.
Prerequisites: Recommended: Prior cloud or distributed systems coursework

Description: Introduces fundamental AI principles and use cases, with emphasis on modern challenges from IoT and AI integration.
Prerequisites: General CS/AI familiarity helpful

Description: Teaches development and application of HPC systems. Covers hardware, architecture, system software, algorithms, and performance management for demanding scientific and industrial problems.
Prerequisites: Recommended: Some experience with systems programming or computing frameworks

Description: Learn how to build intelligent algorithms and software for medical imaging to help doctors and researchers. Topics include tracking, denoising, warping, segmentation, model fitting, optimization, and interactive visualization of medical datasets.

Covers modeling and simulation of material behavior at the nanoscale. Discusses control of shape, assembly, flow in soft nanomaterials. Emphasizes optimization methods, nonequilibrium systems, and parallel computing.
Covers relational and object-oriented database models, database design theory, query processing, application development, and transaction management.
Prerequisites: CSCI-C 241, C 335, and C 343 recommended

Description: Focus on algorithm models, summations, recurrences, and performance analysis. Covers sorting, selection, graphs, spanning trees, and information extraction algorithms.
Design and analysis of algorithms using divide-and-conquer, optimization, and randomization. Includes trees, heaps, hash tables, and graphs.
Covers statistical inference, analysis of variance, linear regression, probability models, and statistical theory including the plug-in principle and maximum likelihood.
Prerequisites: MATH M212, M301, M303 or equivalent

Description: Theory and practice of constructing algorithms that learn functions and choose optimal decisions from data and knowledge. Topics include: mathematical/probabilistic foundations, MAP classification/regression, linear and logistic regression, neural networks, support vector machines, Bayesian networks, tree models, committee machines, kernel functions, EM, density estimation, accuracy estimation, normalization, model selection.

Algorithmic and practical aspects of discovering patterns and relationships in large databases. The course also provides hands-on experience in data analysis, clustering and prediction. Topics include data preprocessing and exploration, data warehousing, association rule mining, classification and regression, clustering, anomaly detection, human factors and social issues in data mining.

Covers programming models and tools of cloud computing to support data-intensive science applications. Includes research topics of cloud platforms, parallel algorithms, storage, and high-level languages.
Prerequisites: Experience with Windows or Linux using Java and scripts

Course Title: Management, Access, and Use of Big and Complex Data
Description: Focuses on data integration, semantics, provenance, workflows, pipelines, and distributed noSQL stores.
Covers relational databases, SQL, and NoSQL databases like XML database, MongoDB, Neo4j, Cassandra, and HBase.
Focuses on algorithm design, implementation, and analysis for real-world problems including sorting, searching, and graph analysis.
Introduction to major issues and approaches in AI. Covers agents, problem-solving, knowledge representation, inference, reasoning, planning, and machine learning.
Prerequisites: CSCI-C 343 recommended

Description: Covers relational and object-oriented databases, relational design theory, efficient data access, query languages, and transaction management.
Prerequisites: CSCI-C 241, C 335 and C 343 recommended

Description: Algorithmic and practical aspects of discovering patterns and relationships in large databases. Hands-on experience in data analysis, clustering, and prediction. Topics: data preprocessing, exploration, warehousing, association rule mining, classification, regression, clustering, anomaly detection, human factors, and social issues in data mining.
Concepts and methods of machine vision as a branch of AI. Basics of digital image processing. Tools for deriving information from image data. Model-based object recognition and scene understanding.
Focuses on applying machine learning algorithms to real-world data. Emphasizes hands-on experience over theory.
Advanced signal processing as an ML application. Hands-on tasks to build intelligent signal processing systems.
Introduction to information retrieval theories and techniques used in modern search engines.
Build foundational skills in ML, NLP, and AI for data collection, analysis, visualization, and decision-making.
Covers theories and applications of network science in social and biological systems. Requires proficiency in math and programming.
Prerequisites: Strong math & programming knowledge

Description: Working knowledge of visualizing abstract information with hands-on domain-specific applications.
Cognition and perception principles, visualization techniques in various domains, use of modern tools.
Overview of organizational behavior, ICT, knowledge management, and analytics in dynamic environments.

Course Title: Social and Organizational Informatics of Big Data
Description: Legal, political, and social impacts of big data on organizational structures and culture.
Focus on maintaining and preserving digital data, including practical experience and planning.
Team-based projects applying data science to real-world problems with guidance from sponsors.
Capstone project covering theory and practice in Information Architecture, guided by a project advisor.
